beats.label: THE SCORES — Top 8
beats.narration: The numbers. All fourteen of them. Logistics. 3 out of 5. Gets the job done. Nothing fancy. Packet pickup at S&S Fire Pits near Hartsfield-Jackson includes beverages, fire, and s'mores—thoughtful community building rather than grab-and-go efficiency. Length. 3 out of 5. Long enough to matter. Short enough to recover. Fast times show the challenge: Jason Thomas's personal best of 1h 23m for 19. Experience. 3 out of 5. You'll remember this one. Mostly fondly. Post-race includes "enough to make you happy and then some"—feast with vegetarian and meat options, drinks, entertainment, plus free photography downloads. Community. 3 out of 5. Genuine community feel. People stick around. Registration proceeds fund MTB Atlanta trail building and maintenance, connecting racing to local trail advocacy. Value. 3 out of 5. Fair value. You get what you pay for. Expenses. 3 out of 5. Mid-range expenses. Budget a proper race weekend. $5 parking at Cochran Mill Park and proximity to Atlanta keep costs minimal. Technicality. 2 out of 5. Some chunky bits. Nothing catastrophic. Mark Hurley describes "some gravel packed and other loose" surface conditions throughout the route. Elevation. 2 out of 5. Rolling terrain. Nothing that'll break you. Kevin Akers describes "lots of hills that are brutal when you're tired," capturing how the rolling terrain accumulates difficulty over distance.
beats.editing_note: PROGRESSIVE RHYTHM: start tight (15-20 sec per dimension), slow down for the most interesting scores (30-40 sec). Each score: number appears, brief pause, explanation. Avatar reacts to extreme scores (5/5 = chef_kiss, 1/5 = facepalm). RE-ENGAGEMENT at 3:00 mark: insert a surprising score reveal or a meme reaction to break the pattern.

beats.narration: Verdict: Metro Atlanta Regional Gravel. If you're in Georgia and want a local rolling gravel event near Atlanta. yes, it's a solid regional race. If you're from out of state. there are better options.
